legislation.statute: Established in 2002, California's Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) was last updated in April 2011. This law requires all electricity retailers in the state acheive the goal of 33% of retail sales from renewables by 2020. The RPS program is administered in tandem by the California Energy Commission and the California Public Utilities Commission.

rps_tech_details.name: Eligible Technologies
rps_tech_details.description: Solar Thermal Electric, Photovoltaics, Landfill Gas, Wind, Biomass, Geothermal Electric, Municipal Solid Waste, Energy Storage, Anaerobic Digestion, Small Hydroelectric, Tidal Energy, Wave Energy, Ocean Thermal, Biodiesel, Fuel Cells using Renewable Fuels

rps_tech_details.name: Geographic Eligibility
rps_tech_details.description: As of 2011 limited trading of RECs produced in the 14 states and two Canadian provinces of the Western Electricity Coordiniating Council (WECC) can count towards a utilities RPS requirement. Up to 25% of a utilities requirements can be accounted for through eligible RECs for the compliance period ending in 2013, 15% for the compliance period ending in 2016 and 10% thereafter.

rps_tech_details.name: Percent of Total Load
rps_tech_details.description: 98.2%; includes IOUs, municipal utilities, and ESP/CCAs

rps_tech_details.name: Technology Requirements
rps_tech_details.description: No technology minimums stated, storage requirements being considered

rps_tech_details.name: Sectors
rps_tech_details.description: Investor-owned utilities (IOUs), municipal utilities, and electricity service providers (ESPs)/community choice aggregators (CCAs)

rps_tech_details.name: Penalty
rps_tech_details.description: $0.05/kWh non-compliance penalty; limited to $25 million annually per provider

legislation.carveouts: California does not have any minimum technology requirements at this time.
legislation.cost_cap_details:
Retailers are required to meet renewable targets provided that sufficient funds are available in the state's 'virtual' fund designed to cover just and reasonable above market costs for new renewable energy resources. If funds are insufficient to cover procurement of renewable power, retailers are allowed to limit their annual procurement obligation.

overview: 33% of the state's energy consumption must be from renewable sources by 2020 subject to the cost cap
Enacted 2002—one of the first and most aggresive in the country
snapshot.policy_trajectory: Most states define a pathway to 'ramp-up' the amount of renewable energy that must be sold. This chart allows you to compare your state's policy pathway to its neighbors. California's pathway is red. Click on another state to learn more about their RPS.
snapshot.summary: California's Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) establishes a minimum amount of renewable energy that must be sold by the state's electricity providers. This page identifies and describes the features of the RPS and how they work together to define the minimum amount of renewable energy that will be sold in California.
